title: Was Joseph Stalin above the law? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a lot of subtlety to this question. First, let’s ask what it means to be above the law. I can see at least two different ways you can interpret it: A person who can do actions that are outside of what the law formally allows, but there are no consequences for thisA person whose wishes simply can become the lawIf you think about it naively you might say that only the first person is “above the law”. For example, Louis XIV, who said “I am the state”, or Russian Czars who formally had the title of “Autocrat of All Russia”, or Roman dictators would not be above the law because the law provided that anything they did was lawful. Note that this does not mean that they could do literally anything (because they would face rebellion if they did), but they could do almost anything they needed to. To me, however, the distinction between the two groups is not a very relevant distinction today, and I would say that both are above the law. Let’s take a more recent example like Putin. He is generally very scrupulous in observing the forms of the law, but he has the ability to change the Russian constitution and any law he pleases, and does so. He is not quite above the law the same way a Czar was because he is more constrained in what he can do before it would trigger a backlash, but he can do anything he choses politically. Now, let’s look at Stalin. Stalin was never the official head of the Soviet state, it’s even arguable whether he was the official head of the All-Russia Communist Party, he was simply the head of its Secretariat, as General Secretary. During the war he was also the Soviet prime-minister (not the head of state) and minister of defense. For much of his time in power he had very limited legal powers. But, critically, this was by choice. He had absolute and complete control of the state, and when he decided he wanted to, he was given any government positions he chose by his “colleagues”, and he would give them away when he no longer needed them. He could give orders and expect them to be carried out without question. He generally did these in a perfectly legal way. He would say to his colleagues, “There is an opinion that such and such is the way to go”, they would agree unanimously, documents will be prepared and signed by appropriate people, and things will go forward. All of the arrests of senior officials were first formally approved by the Politburo or the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, and carried out by the People’s Commissioner (i.e. Minister) for State Security under his authority, and they all went to formal trials, with convictions duly entered and executions carried out. If Stalin decided to commute someone’s sentence (not something he could legally do in 1937), it was officially done by the head of state (Mikhail Kalinin). Anything extra-legal would simply be made legal after the fact, or in fact used to punish officials Stalin wanted punished (called out as “violations of Socialist justice/jurisprudence”). My own opinion is that very little that Stalin ever did was contrary to the Soviet law at the time, formally speaking. At the same time, informally speaking, he could and did absolutely anything he chose without worrying about complying with the substance of the law, but only following its forms. His actions then were made compliant with the law, sometimes simply by changing the law.

Of course he was, he was a dictator!  Let me explain. You may not like what you are going to hear, but I have to say it anyways. All adulterers must be stoned, all homosexuals will go to hell/or be killed.” Then you have your other side that says, “But that’s not possible, you cannot kill its a sin!” Anyone can believe one or the other, that’s why religion is so polarizing.
